channel.title: [VFX] Meteor
channel.description:
New topic cause this one is very different. This is the final test shot. Haha sounds funny.
This is the last of my test shots before the actual movie, and doubles as my special effects project.
That's why there's three takes. The final shot, a slowed version to see the details, and the raw footage.
Let it play through once, for me it only shows like four frames the first go round. Then click play again to restart it and it'll be fine.
http://vimeo.com/2432989

item.title: [VFX] Meteor
item.dc:creator: @Freddy1990 Freddy1990
item.description:
@Freddy1990 wrote:

Cool, now make a spaceship with a giant laser that blows the neighborhood to pieces like in independence day!

Read full topic

item.title: [VFX] Meteor
item.dc:creator: @sanga282 sanga282
item.description:
@sanga282 wrote:

just as the meteor is about to hit it gets a sort of little white halo around it, also i think the framents bounce a little too much

Read full topic

item.title: [VFX] Meteor
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

[quote=“Archer, post:4, topic:248769”][quote author=SomethingToHide link=topic=327883.msg2567184#msg2567184 date=1228443680]

Just a couple things I noticed:
-The heavier chunks need ALOT less bounce, imo.
-The meteor layer should be turned off after it hits the ground, or at least add some deeper smoke layers to hide the fact that it sits completely unscathed after the explosion.
-Add an outer glow to the fire layer as it falls from the sky, this way the fire protrudes from the sides as opposed to the rock just being atop the fire with no blending.

And should feel heavier. Right now they look like a bunch of binders lol.

It’s mostly covered by smoke, but I did add some chunks kinda like the meteor rose up the ground.

Blending is still being though out. The problem with using Max for the meteor and chunks and Cinema for the fire/smoke and After Effects for the dust, is layering them. One has to be on top of each other unless I get into rotoscoping them or figuring out a set of zdepth passes.

But this project is due tonight so I didn’t get into that.
[/quote]

I think its pretty good for the time you were given to do this, but exps covered the crit for me.[/quote]

OH YEAH I forgot I only told you that.

All of this was done in less than 24hours minus rendering time.

I shot the footage Wednesday morning, and went straight to work. Project was due this afternoon. So after work I spent a LOT of time setting all the basic shit up. Then let both programs render overnight. Fucked some of it up so I rendered it again while I was at school. Came home, and then composited and did all of the video editing and effects.

All in all, I spent about a half a day on this.

Read full topic

item.title: [VFX] Meteor
item.dc:creator: @archerer98 Archer
item.description:
@archerer98 wrote:

[quote=“SomethingToHide, post:3, topic:248769”][quote author=exps35 link=topic=327883.msg2567180#msg2567180 date=1228443521]
Just a couple things I noticed:
-The heavier chunks need ALOT less bounce, imo.
-The meteor layer should be turned off after it hits the ground, or at least add some deeper smoke layers to hide the fact that it sits completely unscathed after the explosion.
-Add an outer glow to the fire layer as it falls from the sky, this way the fire protrudes from the sides as opposed to the rock just being atop the fire with no blending.
[/quote]

And should feel heavier. Right now they look like a bunch of binders lol.

It’s mostly covered by smoke, but I did add some chunks kinda like the meteor rose up the ground.

Blending is still being though out. The problem with using Max for the meteor and chunks and Cinema for the fire/smoke and After Effects for the dust, is layering them. One has to be on top of each other unless I get into rotoscoping them or figuring out a set of zdepth passes.

But this project is due tonight so I didn’t get into that.[/quote]

I think its pretty good for the time you were given to do this, but exps covered the crit for me.

Read full topic

-Add an outer glow to the fire layer as it falls from the sky, this way the fire protrudes from the sides as opposed to the rock just being atop the fire with no blending.[/quote]

Blending is still being though out. The problem with using Max for the meteor and chunks and Cinema for the fire/smoke and After Effects for the dust, is layering them. One has to be on top of each other unless I get into rotoscoping them or figuring out a set of zdepth passes.

But this project is due tonight so I didn’t get into that.
